Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Origami Design for Integration of Self-assembling Systemsfor Engineering Innovation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Folding and unfolding materials to create structures with novel shape and functionality has been recognized as a promising design concept for engineering systems at and across a broad range of length scales. This workshop will bring together a diverse group of international experts to discuss and explore challenges and opportunities in the emerging field of origami design. The workshop will be held on May 14, 2013, in Orlando, Florida, directly subsequent to the 10th World Congress on Structural and Multidisciplinary Optimization (WCSMO-10). WCSMO-10 is considered the primary conference series in topology optimization, an approach that is particularly promising for origami design. In addition to internationally renowned leaders in computational design and topology optimization, researchers of current NSF EFRI ODISSEI projects will be invited.

The focus of the workshop will be on the fundamental principles of origami design. The main goals are to (a) identify the intrinsic challenges of designing structures that fold and unfold at various and across length scales, and (b) explore opportunities for design optimization, in particular topology optimization, to systematically design (unfolding) structures. The workshop will result in a comprehensive understanding of the current capabilities of topology optimization for origami design and the new challenges origami design poses for the design optimization community. The workshop will educate materials, device, and structural design researchers on systematic approaches to origami design, and it will pose novel, exciting problems to the topology optimization community. The workshop will bring together both senior researchers and their graduate students from around the globe, thus planting the seed for new domestic and international collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This workshop brought together a diverse group of international experts to discuss and explore challenges and opportunities in the emerging field of origami design. A total of 57 faculty, students, and representatives from industry and DOD labs met on May 24 in Orlando, FL. The workshop was held directly subsequent to the10th World Congress on Structural and Multidisciplinary Optimization (WCSMO-10) which is one of the key conferences on computational design optimization.  In addition to participants of WCSMO-10, team members of 7 NSF EFRI ODISSEEI projects and 3 members of the AFRL origami design project attended the workshop. Through a series of presentations and break-out sessions the participants discussed the ability and utility of current computational design optimization methods for the design for foldable structures. The focus of the discussions was on topology optimization which represents the most general and versatile design optimization approach. A broad consensus was found that todays' topology optimization methods provide a promising tool set for origami design but they need to be enhanced to cope with the nonlinearity and time-dependence of folding processes. Further, the proper formulation of the optimization problem in terms of objectives and constraints are currently unknown. It is also not clear whether gradient-based search algorithms are suitable of origami design due the large configurational changes the structures undergoes in the folding process. Finally, the participants recommended investigating the influence of uncertainty on origami designs as the ability to fold and unfold is significantly impacted by imprecise crease patterns and variations in material properties.
